awd_titl_txt: Decoding Urban Ecosystems: Computational Thinking Integration in Middle School STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
As a result of the powerful innovation and application of computing in STEM disciplines, the STEM+C program addresses an urgent need for real-world, interdisciplinary, and computational preparation of students from the early grades through high school (preK-12). The American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), in collaboration with Project GUTS (Growing Up Thinking Scientifically), will undertake a three-year research project to design, implement, and evaluate a youth-centered program that engages New York City (NYC) middle school students in a new computational thinking (CT)-integrated science curriculum. In this curriculum, students will simultaneously engage with ecosystem dynamics and use CT practices in the context of computer modeling and simulations, including abstraction, automation (including algorithmic thinking, debugging, and iteration) analysis, and generalization through computer modeling and simulation. The project research aims to deepen understanding of student learning and active engagement with authentic science practices when students are given supports to make connections between CT in coding and decoding of computer models and scientific processes. In addition, the curriculum design will explicitly connect STEM content to the professional practices of the field, thereby contributing to existing literature on effective approaches. 

Through this project, 125 students will participate in a new, CT-integrated ecosystems curriculum. These participants will be recruited from schools that predominantly serve low-income families who are representative of the socioeconomic, ethnic, and gender diversity of NYC. The project will also engage four NYC teachers as co-researchers. Data to be collected include modified versions of existing knowledge assessment and survey instruments, artifact-based interviews conducted with students, and recorded observations of instruction. Pre-post analysis will be conducted to identify learning gains, and a modified interaction analysis within and between data sources will be conducted to illuminate relationships between students' analysis of computational models and development of mechanistic understandings of ecosystems.  Findings will be broadly disseminated and will inform the design of a professional learning program for NYC middle school teachers. The tested curriculum will be available on Project GUTS' open professional development network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop and test an out of school time curriculum that focused on teaching middle schoolers to decode models, or mapping mechanisms in code to processes in science, as a step towards validating or improving models.  In particular, we used agent-based modeling to teach about the Lyme disease ecosystem. Decoding is mapping mechanisms in code to processes in science. We wanted to investigate whether and how decoding enables students to deepen their scientific understanding of complex systems.  

The program took place at the American Museum of Natural History. The program design included a 70-hour summer program followed by a 2-day continuation workshop six months later to evaluate learning retention and transfer. Three cohorts of students over three years engaged in the program). The students were racially and socioeconomic diverse representing public schools in New York City. In terms of gender, Cohort 1 identified as two-thirds female and Cohorts 2 and 3 identified as two-thirds male. The curriculum was designed on the Use-Modify-Create progression and decoding was embedded into each stage. For example, in the Use stage, students run and interpret code within models. In doing the activity, students identify specific code segments that represent real-world mechanisms OR identify real world mechanisms being represented in code by rearranging the code blocks to represent the stages in a tick’s life cycle. In the Modify stage, students had to change the existing code within models but do so reflecting their understanding of real-world mechanisms. An example of the challenge presented is, “what do you think will happen with the population of acorns, mice and foxes in the model over time if the foxes can eat both mice and acorns?” In the Create stage, students write their own code in the models corresponding to real world mechanisms. In the project, groups were asked to select an organism that could impact the ecosystem and accurately code for the activity of the organism and its impact. Choices were turkey, dog, squirrel and opossum.

The data was collected via knowledge/skills surveys, artifact-based interviews, classroom observations and exit tickets. Data was collected pre/post the summer workshop and after the continuation workshop. A comparison group was also selected and completed surveys. The survey included items on ecosystem concepts, CS concepts, and decoding tasks. The artifact-based interviews had two sections – one that probed students’ approach to mechanistic reasoning and one that inquired about computational thinking skills and being able to translate what the sections of code that mediated the activity in the scientific model. The specific scenarios were different in the pre/post and continuation interviews.

 

A paired t-test showed that treatment group students on average significantly improved their overall KS-CT scores after the workshop (pre: Mean = 9.435, (SD = 3.304), post: Mean = 12.174 (SD = 4.073), p < .01). This means that DecodeNYC intervention positively impacted students’ CT, science learning and decoding as compared to a comparison group. Of the treatment group students who participated in all three surveys (n = 27), We found no statistically significant difference between post- and continuation scores 6 months after the intervention (post: Mean = 14.000, (SD = 3.223), continuation: Mean = 13.667 (SD = 3.584), p = .390). This suggests that students did not lose knowledge and skills after a six-month hiatus. Interview data confirmed these results and provided us with specific instances of how students retained knowledge and were able to use decoding to transfer understanding to new ecosystem scenarios.

 

Intellectual Merit: Scholars have established that complex systems are difficult for middle school students to grasp and ecosystem dynamics are particularly challenging. . Decoding skills were found to impact students’ ability to reason about new scientific phenomena in the following ways: decoding was used to a) correct misconceptions about causality, b) support thinking about the generators of phenomena, c) support the use of code as a scaffold for running thought experiments, d) support creating accurate models of ecosystems by referring to real world mechanisms, and e) support reasoning about causal relationships in new phenomena and their impact on the larger system (by leveraging previously learned causal chains).

 

Broader Impacts: The key takeaways are that student gains in decoding are correlated with mechanistic reasoning about the properties and behaviors of agents as well as their causal relationships. skills in code, that decoding deepens both CT and science learning by enabling students to use the CT they learned to make sense of processes in science. Decoding also supports the learning of the causal structure of an ecosystem, including the ability to use that causal structure to make predictions. This curriculum continues to be used at the American Museum of Natural History and has inspired several offshoots that are of various lengths to accommodate weekend and week-long learning programs and reach a larger number of audiences.
